item.title: CI/CD for Frappe Bench using Jenkins
item.description:
CI/CD for Frappe Bench using Jenkins (Offline / Air-Gapped Setup)

This guide explains how to implement safe CI/CD with rollback for a Frappe Bench application using Docker and Jenkins, when the production server has NO internet access.

This approach is widely used in banks, government infra, and enterprise ERP deployments.

1. Problem Statement

  • Frappe Bench applications require schema migrations
  • Docker images must be deployed without pulling from internet
  • Rollback must restore both code and database
  • Deployment must be repeatable, auditable, and safe

2. High-Level Architecture

item.title: Deploying ERPNext Frappe with Docker in Offline Air-Gapped Environment
item.description:
üöÄ Deploying ERPNext (Frappe) with Docker in an Offline / Air-Gapped Environment

From Local Setup to Server Deployment (Complete Guide)

1. Why This Guide Exists

In many enterprise environments:

  • Internet access is restricted or completely blocked
  • Servers are accessible only via SSH
  • Docker images must be pre-approved
  • Production servers cannot pull images from Docker Hub

This guide shows how to:

  • Build an offline Docker image bundle (.tar)
  • Transfer it to a remote server
  • Load and run ERPNext (Frappe) fully offline
  • Operate backend, database, and workers safely
  • Fix common real-world issues (ports, frontend crashes, networking)

Everything here is battle-tested.

item.title: Docker Container
item.description:
Managing Docker Containers Like a Pro

‚öôÔ∏è 1. What is a Docker Container?

A container is a running instance of a Docker image ‚Äî a lightweight, isolated environment that can hold your software, tools, and files.

  • Image = the blueprint (a frozen snapshot, like an OS or preconfigured setup)
  • Container = the living instance of that image

When you stop or delete a container, your data and changes can vanish ‚Äî unless you know how to make them persistent.

item.description:
How to Create and Manage Docker Networks

üîπ What Is a Docker Network?

A Docker network is a virtual layer that connects containers. By default, Docker provides some basic network types:

Network Type Description
bridge Default network for standalone containers. Containers can talk to each other by name on the same bridge.
host Shares the host machine‚Äôs network directly (no isolation).
none Disables networking for the container.
overlay Enables communication between containers across multiple Docker hosts (used in Swarm mode).
macvlan Assigns a MAC address to containers, making them appear as physical devices on your LAN.

item.description:
docker run -d –name mariadb –network frappe-net -e MYSQL_ROOT_PASSWORD=frappe -e MYSQL_USER=frappe -e MYSQL_PASSWORD=frappe -e MYSQL_DATABASE=frappe -v mariadb_data:/var/lib/mysql -p 3307:3306 mariadb:10.6

–name redis-cache
–network frappe-net
-p 13000:6379

–name redis-queue
–network frappe-net
-p 11000:6379

–name redis-socketio
–network frappe-net
